posts.name: ATEMS Robotics
posts.cooked: We are entering our Rookie year and have seen that wiring tends to be a big reason for robot problems in past games. Are there any Tips, Tricks, or Tools you guys have to help our new team properly prepare our wiring for competitions and make a reliable robot? We are running a fully CTRE system with the exception of our REV PD and mini PD boards. We will have 2 CAN loops (CANivore+ RIO). Any good wiring practices will be useful. I just want us to practice the right way now to get in the habit before competition.

posts.name: Galen Spooner
posts.cooked: Connectors are the most critical failure points, you should hot glue basically every single one

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC 2035 Captain, Software Lead, Driver, Design

posts.custom_user_title: FRC 2035 Captain, Software Lead, Driver, Design

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked:
There seem to be 10 threads a week on this subject.

Getting good connectors and learning how to make them (e.g crimp them) properly is 99% of what you need to do to ensure a reliable robot during competition.

Standards these days are Anderson Power Pole for wires 20 AWG or larger, Molex SL for wires 22 AWG or smaller.

posts.name: Brian Rozmierski
posts.cooked:
GalenSpooner mentioned securing all your connectors with hot glue.

While I don’t know about going that for for every connector of every type, I agree with their overall sentiment. Wiring should be attached firmly and not susceptible to, shall we say, premature disconnection .

For PP45 connectors that may mean making sure to connect the individual connectors into a pair or block, and using something like a zip tie (cheap, easy to cut and replace) to provide additional retention.

For things like Wago connectors, that would mean fully and properly following the device manufacturer’s instructions on proper strip and insertion length. This may also mean installing the individual connectors into a mounting block to firmly attach to your chassis to reduce the effect of sudden stops or hits from your robot affecting the wiring.

For other connector types, like the IO ports on the sides of the RoboRIO, I do recommend a dab of hot glue on the side of the  connector and edge of the RoboRIO. Something about the size of a large water droplet. Mentors should supervise, at least in the case of my team as I’m sure they’d have cocooned the entire RoboRIO in hot glue has we left them to it…

Simply put - when in doubt, lock it down.

posts.name: usbcd36
posts.cooked:
Find every presentation you can on FRC wiring and read or watch them all; it’ll be more comprehensive than this thread.  Search ChiefDelphi, YouTube, and the internet at large.  As ArchdukeTim said, this is a common question, but a ChiefDelphi thread isn’t the best way to present wiring advice.

If nothing else, leave plenty of time to perform the “run your robot full-speed into a brick wall” test before you go to competition.  Do this a few times, learn what broke (wiring or otherwise) and use that information to improve your robot.

posts.name: Nick Foote
posts.cooked: We just did a write up about our wiring in our OA thread, but honestly, as a rookie team, my biggest advice is that you need to consider where your wiring is going when designing and fabricating your robot. If you just wait until the after the mechanical part is done and assume it’s all gonna work itself out, you’re gonna be in for a world of pain.

posts.name: Matthew K
posts.cooked: always ziptie your battery connector. make sure your battery is strapped down so it doesn’t hit anything and unplug it
